section: Overview of Hakone Hot Springs and Tourist Information
content: Hakone has long been known as a hot spring resort for "thermal cure" (tōji), with hot springs bubbling up in the mountains, plus museums, gardens, historic shrines, ropeways, and sightseeing boats. It is about 1 hour by train from Tokyo and can be enjoyed as a day trip or overnight stay. The Hakone Town Comprehensive Tourist Information Center provides general guidance on routes and seasonal recommendations; phone 0460-85-5700, hours 9:00–17:45, open year-round. The official site "Hakone All Mountains" and accommodation site "Hakopita" are also useful. The "Hakone Tourism Digital Map" lets you check transport, dining, traffic, crowds, parking availability, and coupons on your smartphone. The AI travel plan service "Travel Style Diagnosis" suggests optimal sightseeing routes based on your preferences.

section: Hakone Seventeen Hot Springs and Spring Characteristics
content: Hakone is known as one of Japan's leading hot spring resorts, with 17 areas called "Hakone Seventeen Hot Springs," each with different spring qualities and atmospheres. Representative areas include Yumoto with its concentration of inns and restaurants, Gora with a calm highland feel, and Sengokuhara known for its pampas grass fields. Spring types include simple hot springs, sulfur springs, and chloride springs, and Hakone's appeal lies in enjoying a hot spring tour tailored to your preferences. Many facilities offer day-trip bathing; Hakone Kowakien Yunessun features a swimsuit-friendly hot spring amusement park and the full-scale day-trip bath "Mori no Yu." Tenzan Onsenkyo in Yumoto is a day-trip hot spring facility with free-flowing spring water, open 9:00–22:00 year-round.

Hakone offers various vehicles that let you enjoy the scenery while getting around. The Hakone Tozan Railway, opened in 1919, is Japan's only full-scale mountain railway, climbing steep slopes via switchbacks with varied views of tunnels and iron bridges. The Hakone Tozan Cable Car is a unique ride that tilts as it climbs the slope. The Hakone Ropeway offers an aerial stroll with views of Mt. Fuji and Lake Ashi. The Komagatake Ropeway runs from Hakone-en to the summit of Mt. Komagatake. The Hakone Pirate Ship departs from Togendai Port for cruises on Lake Ashi, with views from luxurious special cabins. From Togendai Port to Motohakone Port takes about 25 minutes, and to Hakone-machi Port about 10 minutes. Lake Ashi sightseeing boats also offer scenic views from the water. The amphibious ninja bus is a thrilling activity that dives into Lake Ashi. From Shinjuku, take the Odakyu Line to Hakone-Yumoto Station, or use the Shinkansen to Odawara Station and transfer.

Hakone is dotted with various museums. The Hakone Open-Air Museum was Japan's first open-air museum, where you can stroll among outdoor sculptures by master artists. It includes the Picasso Pavilion and features "Star Garden" (a star-shaped maze) and "Net Forest" (a giant net playground) for children. A foot bath on the grounds lets you rest while viewing art. Hours are 9:00–17:00, open year-round. The Pola Museum of Art blends into the forest landscape, displaying works from Monet and Van Gogh to contemporary art, with exceptional walks along the "Forest Path." The Okada Museum of Art has a vast five-floor space with about 450 Japanese and East Asian works on permanent display, plus a foot bath cafe with 100% free-flowing spring water. The Hakone Museum of Art is Hakone's oldest museum, exhibiting "yakimono" (ceramics) from Jomon pottery to the Edo period, and is also popular for autumn foliage. The Hakone Lalique Museum showcases René Lalique's glasswork, and you can enjoy tea time inside a restored "Orient Express" car.

section: Hakone Natural Spots and Scenic Views
content: Hakone has many spots where you can experience dramatic nature. Owakudani, once called "Jigokudani" (Hell Valley), features hot springs bubbling up from the ground. You can stroll the nature trail amid rising steam while trying the famous black eggs. Lake Ashi is Hakone's representative lake, offering seasonal nature, sightseeing boats, and superb views of Mt. Fuji, with the Hakone Checkpoint ruins and Hakone Shrine nearby. Senjo Falls stands in a quiet wooded spot, with many thin streams of water creating a mystical scene and abundant negative ions. Hiryū Falls is a powerful large waterfall; visiting both Senjo and Hiryū reveals the depth of Hakone's nature. Sengokuhara Pampas Grass Field is a spectacular spot where golden pampas grass spreads across the landscape in autumn. Onshi Hakone Park is the site of a former imperial villa built for the imperial family in the Meiji period, famous for its views of Lake Ashi and Mt. Fuji.

Hakone Shrine stands on the shore of Lake Ashi and is known for good fortune and traffic safety, a long-revered power spot. It is also known for matchmaking and auspicious unions; walking the cedar-lined approach offers views of the "Peace Torii" on the lake. The amulet and charm office is open 8:15–17:00. Kuzuryū Shrine is known as a sacred site for matchmaking, with a new hall on the grounds of Hakone Shrine and the main hall on the lakeshore. At the summit of Mt. Komagatake is Hakone Motomiya, the inner shrine of Hakone Shrine; a three-shrine pilgrimage to Hakone Shrine, Kuzuryū Shrine, and Hakone Motomiya is recommended. Sounji Temple enshrines the warlord Hojo Soun; its quiet grounds preserve the graves of successive Hojo lords and a beautiful garden. Mt. Fuji, a World Heritage site, can be seen from many places in Hakone.

Hakone has 24 hiking courses suitable for beginners to advanced hikers. Yusaka Road (Kamakura Ancient Road) appears in the Kamakura-period "Izayoi Nikki" and was used as the route over Hakone until the Edo period. It is beginner-level (difficulty ★), about 6.5 km, walking time about 210 minutes, from Yusaka Road entrance via Yusaka Castle ruins, Shiroyama, Asama-yama, and Takanosu-yama to Ashinoyu. There are bathing facilities near the goal, and enjoying a hot spring after hiking is a classic. The Hakone Old Road course starts at Amazake Chaya and follows the old road with cedar trees and stone paving to the Hakone Checkpoint ruins; elevation gain 120 m, distance 3.1 km, walking time about 90 minutes, suitable for beginners. Mt. Kintoki is one of Japan's 300 Famous Mountains and the setting of "Kintaro"; the course features "Kintoki Yadori Stone" and "Temari Stone" along the way. Elevation gain 450 m, one-way 2.1 km, walking time about 170 minutes. Long sleeves, long pants, hat, backpack, and non-slip hiking boots are recommended.

Hakone has many spots for outdoor and craft experiences. Forest Adventure Hakone in Yumoto is a full-scale nature-based outdoor park where you can try ziplines, suspension bridges, and other obstacle courses. Lake Ashi Camp Village offers BBQ lunch plus Segway nature guide tours and mountain bike tours. At Hakone Craft House in Hakone Gora Park, you can create one-of-a-kind pieces through glassblowing, pottery, glass beads, sandblasting, cut glass, and laser engraving. The Hatano-juku Yosegi Kaikan offers Hakone's traditional craft "Hakone Yosegi Marquetry" for purchase and coaster-making workshops. Hours are 9:30–16:30, closed Mondays and year-end/new-year.

Hakone has many spots to enjoy the changing face of nature through the seasons. In spring, cherry blossoms at Miyaginoda Early River Embankment and the azalea garden at Odakyu Hotel de Yama are at their best. The Miyaginoda Festival is held in April. In summer, hydrangeas along the Hakone Tozan Railway are beautiful, and the Lake Festival is held on Lake Ashi on July 31. On August 16, the Hakone Daimonji Festival is held in Gora and Miyaginoda, and is one of Kanagawa's 50 Selected Festivals. In autumn, the pampas grass field in Sengokuhara and autumn foliage at the Hakone Museum of Art are spectacular; the Hakone Daimyo Procession is held in Yumoto in November. In winter, the Hakone Museum of Art's illumination is beautiful, and the Tokyo–Hakone Round-Trip University Ekiden Relay is held on National Route 1 on January 2–3. On February 3, Setsubun Festival is held at Hakone Shrine.

Hakone is located at the western edge of Kanagawa Prefecture, adjacent to Tokyo, and is about 1 hour by train from Tokyo. The Odakyu Line runs direct Romancecar limited express trains from Shinjuku Station to Hakone-Yumoto Station. By Shinkansen, take the Tokaido Shinkansen to Odawara Station and transfer to the Hakone Tozan Line for Hakone-Yumoto Station. By car, access via the Tomei Expressway at Atsugi IC, Odawara-Higashi IC, or Gotemba IC. Hakone-Yumoto Station is at 96 m elevation, Gora Station at 541 m, and Sengokuhara at 640 m; due to the elevation difference, temperatures vary greatly by season and weather. Hakone Tozan Bus and Izu Hakone Bus operate within Hakone. Gora Tourist Information Center: 0460-82-1516; Hakone Pass Tourist Information Center: 0460-83-7310.

Hakone has sightseeing spots you can enjoy with your pet. Hakone no Yu has a gourd-shaped outdoor bath for dogs and private rooms, so you can relax in the hot spring with your pet (reservation required). Hours are 10:00–22:00. The Lake Ashi sightseeing boat "SORAKAZE" allows dogs on board so you can enjoy the lake views with your dog. Hakone-en Aquarium is Japan's highest-altitude saltwater aquarium at 723 m, with nearby restaurants where you can dine with your dog. On the Komagatake Ropeway, dogs in carriers or carts can ride, and you can enjoy the views from the summit. At the Narukawa Art Museum, you can take photos with your dog in the outdoor area. Hakone Kowakien Horai-en is a vast garden where you can walk with your dog. DogHub Hakone Sengokuhara offers daycare and overnight boarding services.

section: Hakone Hot Spring Quality and Efficacy
content: Hakone hot springs offer varied efficacy because spring quality differs by area. Simple hot springs, common in Yumoto and Tonosawa, are mild and are said to help with fatigue recovery, neuralgia, muscle pain, and cold sensitivity; they are safe for children and the elderly. Sulfur springs in Sengokuhara and around Owakudani are said to help chronic skin conditions and atopic dermatitis and have strong antibacterial properties. Chloride springs found in Gora and Miyanoshita have high heat retention and are slow to cool, making them suitable for those with cold sensitivity. Hakone also has bicarbonate springs, known as "beauty springs" for their skin-smoothing effects. Touring the Hakone Seventeen Hot Springs lets you enjoy different spring effects in a single trip, a unique appeal of Hakone.

section: Recommended Ways to Enjoy Hakone Hot Springs
content: A recommended way to enjoy Hakone hot springs is the Golden Course: take the Hakone Tozan Railway and ropeway to Owakudani for the steam and famous black eggs, then enjoy a pirate ship cruise on Lake Ashi with views of Mt. Fuji. For art lovers, the Hakone Open-Air Museum and Pola Museum of Art are popular, with outdoor exhibits blending with nature. For hot springs, try day-trip bathing at Tenzan Onsenkyo with free-flowing spring water, or enjoy Yunessun for fun and bathing. A power spot tour of Hakone Shrine and Kuzuryū Shrine is also recommended. With about 1 hour access from Tokyo, Hakone can be fully enjoyed even on a day trip.

section: Hakone Hot Spring Efficacy and Recommended For
content: Hakone hot springs encompass the diverse Hakone Seventeen Hot Springs, and recommended visitors vary by spring quality. Simple hot springs in Yumoto and Tonosawa are mild and are said to help fatigue recovery, neuralgia, muscle pain, and cold sensitivity; they are ideal for hot spring beginners, children, the elderly, and those with sensitive skin. Sulfur springs in Sengokuhara and Owakudani have strong antibacterial effects and are recommended for chronic skin conditions and atopic dermatitis, but due to their stronger stimulation, those with sensitive skin should bathe for short periods. Chloride springs in Gora and Miyanoshita have high heat retention and suit those with cold sensitivity or who want to warm up in winter. Bicarbonate springs are known as "beauty springs" and smooth the skin, making them popular with women interested in skincare. Hakone's convenient access from Tokyo (about 1 hour) also makes it ideal for businesspeople seeking a quick post-work or weekend getaway.
